physicalObject: grey and white camouflage-pattern wireless game controller
proxyLocation: top left of the white table
utilizationMethod: Hold the controller by slipping your index and middle fingers through the gap created by the two analog sticks and the underside ridge, while the thumb and remaining fingers clamp the front shell. This hook-style grip gives a 2-3 cm thick rounded edge that loosely mimics a mug handle. The controller’s mass (≈250 g) provides moderate inertia so wrist pronation / supination feels like tilting a partially-filled mug.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This mug serves as a drinking vessel, designed to be grasped by the handle
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate weight that feels substantial since it's full. As well as a rotational moment around their grip point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a relatively thin, slender rod approximately 2 cm in diameter. User should sense the handle's curved arc and rounded cross-section.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user will perform a hook-style precision/power hybrid grip on the handle. One or two fingers slide through the 2 cm-diameter wooden rod while the thumb and remaining fingers clamp the outside, forming a small closed loop. The hand stays close to the body and the wrist repeatedly supinates and pronates to lift the mug toward the mouth and then tilt it so liquid flows. Inertia feedback is moderate; as the wrist begins to rotate, the weight of the filled mug produces a noticeable moment that tries to pull the rim downward, so users naturally counter-torque with forearm muscles. The handle remains rigid and slightly rounded, conveying a hard wooden outline with no deformation. Once the mug is set down, the base contacts a surface and quickly stops—no bounce or flex—reinforcing the perception of a solid, full vessel.

physicalObject: tall roll of white paper towel (empty cardboard core)
proxyLocation: top center of the white table
utilizationMethod: Grasp the cardboard tube sideways like a mug by curling two fingers inside the hollow core and placing the thumb on the outside surface; this forms a loop similar to a cup handle. The tube’s light weight can be augmented by simply letting a portion rest against the palm so its length produces a rotational moment when you tilt—approximating the feel of a light, half-full wooden mug.

physicalObject: grey and white camouflage-pattern wireless game controller
proxyLocation: top left of the white tabletop
utilizationMethod: Hold the controller by wrapping your dominant hand around ONE of its hand-grips while letting the bulk of the controller stick out beyond your fist. This creates a head-heavy feeling because most of the mass sits beyond the wrist, mimicking the axe head. Swing the forearm in vertical or diagonal arcs; the asymmetric mass causes a noticeable forward pull similar to a small hatchet.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user employs a strong power grip around the cylindrical wooden handle, wrapping all fingers and thumb in opposition. For heavy swings, the user may add the opposite hand farther down the shaft, creating a two-handed baseball-bat posture. Interaction involves wide shoulder or torso swings in a vertical or diagonal arc, pivoting at the wrist and elbow. Because the head is mass-dominant, the user immediately senses forward pull: as acceleration starts, the heavy metal head lags slightly then whips forward, amplifying centrifugal force; during deceleration or impact, the head continues to carry momentum, requiring arm and wrist braking. The axe itself remains entirely rigid; only its velocity changes in response to user motion, creating a crisp stop when ‘biting’ into a virtual target.

utilizationMethod: Grip the lower half of the cardboard cylinder with a full fist to imitate the axe handle’s circumference. proxyLocation: top left of the yellow table
utilizationMethod: Keep the selfie stick collapsed and grasp the rubberized base grip; the phone clamp and telescoping tubes form a forward-loaded head. Its metal body and length allow either one-handed or two-handed baseball-bat grips, delivering realistic handle girth and convincing head-heavy inertia during wide chopping swings.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user employs a strong power grip around the cylindrical wooden handle, wrapping all fingers and thumb in opposition. For heavy swings, the user may add the opposite hand farther down the shaft, creating a two-handed baseball-bat posture. Interaction involves wide shoulder or torso swings in a vertical or diagonal arc, pivoting at the wrist and elbow. Because the head is mass-dominant, the user immediately senses forward pull: as acceleration starts, the heavy metal head lags slightly then whips forward, amplifying centrifugal force; during deceleration or impact, the head continues to carry momentum, requiring arm and wrist braking. The axe itself remains entirely rigid; only its velocity changes in response to user motion, creating a crisp stop when ‘biting’ into a virtual target.

physicalObject: black stainless steel water bottle with Tesla logo
proxyLocation: right side of the yellow table
utilizationMethod: Grasp the bottle near its narrow neck so the full weight of the liquid-filled body extends below your hand, emulating a thick axe head. The metal’s mass and rigid cylindrical form make every motion feel substantial, reinforcing the power-grip posture described for the axe.

physicalObject: grey and white camouflage-pattern wireless game controller
proxyLocation: lying on the left-hand side of the white tabletop
utilizationMethod: Grasp the controller by one of its hand-grips so that the opposite, bulkier side becomes the 'hammer head.' Swing the controller in a short arc; the asymmetrical mass of the buttons and battery compartment provides a faint but detectable head-heavy feel while the curved grip fills the palm like a short cylindrical handle.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This hammer serves as a striking tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass concentrated in the head, creating a distinctly head-heavy sensation when wielding the hammer.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user wraps the dominant hand in a power grip near the lower third of the handle, optionally adding the second hand for extra force. Interaction consists of repeated lift-and-drop or forward jabbing motions, hinging primarily at the elbow with wrist fine-tuning aim. The head-heavy mass produces pronounced pendulum behavior: during the upswing the head feels sluggish, during the downswing it gains speed and tries to extend the wrist. Upon striking, the virtual head stops abruptly while the handle transmits a simulated jolt up the shaft. The wooden handle outline stays cylindrical and firm, with no noticeable flex, reinforcing the sense of a solid striking tool.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This sickle serves as a harvesting and cutting tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate forward-weighted inertia concentrated in the curved blade, but distributed along the arc rather than at a single point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user grips the short handle in a one-handed power grip, thumb wrapped over the opposing fingers. Because the blade curves forward, normal use involves sweeping, slicing motions that start at shoulder height and finish near the opposite hip or knee. The moderate forward-weighted inertia makes the blade feel present but maneuverable; it subtly tugs outward when the arm initiates a curved slice and carries through even after the wrist begins to decelerate. Users may also perform short wrist flicks for trimming actions. The handle remains stiff and round while the blade never deforms; instead it provides positional feedback by burying into or passing through virtual vegetation, signaling successful cuts through changes in resistance and sound.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This sickle serves as a harvesting and cutting tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate forward-weighted inertia concentrated in the curved blade, but distributed along the arc rather than at a single point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user grips the short handle in a one-handed power grip, thumb wrapped over the opposing fingers. Because the blade curves forward, normal use involves sweeping, slicing motions that start at shoulder height and finish near the opposite hip or knee. The moderate forward-weighted inertia makes the blade feel present but maneuverable; it subtly tugs outward when the arm initiates a curved slice and carries through even after the wrist begins to decelerate. Users may also perform short wrist flicks for trimming actions. The handle remains stiff and round while the blade never deforms; instead it provides positional feedback by burying into or passing through virtual vegetation, signaling successful cuts through changes in resistance and sound.

physicalObject: black telescoping selfie stick with phone holder
proxyLocation: top left of image 2, extended across the table
utilizationMethod: Grip the foam handle; the extended metal shaft acts like the sickle’s shank and the phone clamp supplies mass at the far end, producing forward-weighted inertia. Users can execute wide harvesting sweeps or quick flicks, feeling momentum carry through the tip similar to a curved blade.

physicalObject: black stainless steel water bottle with Tesla logo
proxyLocation: right side of image 2, standing upright
utilizationMethod: Hold the bottle near its narrow neck as a short handle; the filled body provides substantial weight concentrated forward of the grip. Swinging it in an arc creates a believable pull, while the cylindrical outline and hard metal surface replicate the firmness of a tool handle.

proxyLocation: bottom center of image 2 on the tabletop
utilizationMethod: Wrap fingers around one narrow end of the box; the rectangular mass jutting outward symbolizes the blade. The cardboard surface is firm, and sweeping the box side-on through the air allows users to perceive where a curved edge would pass, fulfilling the sickle’s slicing gesture requirement.
